awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Institutional and Community Transformation for Teaching and Learning Quantitative Reasoning in the Biological Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantitative reasoning (QR) involves the use of mathematical skills, such as algebra and statistical analysis, to understand and interpret data.  The field of biology has become increasingly reliant on the use of quantitative reasoning to interpret large datasets, such as those gathered in genomic analysis and population studies.  This project is designed to improve quantitative reasoning skills in students at community colleges preparing to transfer into biology majors at four-year institutions.  These students are often underprepared to successfully complete biology majors and to continue to graduate education or to enter the STEM workforce.  To achieve long-term gains in students' abilities to apply QR in biological contexts, this proposal seeks to leverage a university/community college partnership to expand and deepen the QR content in core biology courses across the major.  The program aspires to provide a model for how consortia of community colleges and universities can facilitate course awareness and alignment to improve student gains in QR.  This project will test the hypothesis that this type of collaboration enhances pedagogy and transfer student success at four-year institutions.  Further, repeated interaction with QR modules within the core biology curricula are hypothesized to positively impact the success of all students in upper-level coursework.  These efforts are designed to strengthen the course performance measures of all students, including both direct entry and transfer students.  Improving student success and retention in STEM majors such as biology supports the goal of improving access of all students to scientific and technical careers.

The focus of the project will be on enhancing the QR skills of undergraduates through the creation of active learning modules focused on quantitative skill development, verified with validated assessment instruments.  Three scholarly communities will be established: 1) a Curricular Alignment Team, which will review curricula in four core courses (Introductory Biology: Cells and Molecules, Introductory Biology: Ecology and Evolution, Genetics, and Cell Biology) at the community colleges and the four-year institution in the collaboration, and identify areas for action, with emphasis on the development of QR abilities in biology majors; 2) the NEXUS Institute in Quantitative Biology, which will involve teams of faculty from each institution developing, piloting, and assessing QR modules for the core biology curricula and assessing the impact on student performance and retention; and 3) a Faculty Development Community, which will involve a series of shared faculty development workshops on evidence-based teaching approaches, to include the use of the created QR modules, and a common teaching certificate program.  These three communities will come together annually at a regional symposium, where the consortium products (QR modules) and findings (student assessment data) will be disseminated.  Taken together, this work will shape intra- and inter-institutional perspectives and practices relating to the importance of QR in the success of undergraduate biology majors.  By developing faculty collaborations through the scholarly communities described above, this project will provide training in modern pedagogical methods and module development for biology faculty at community colleges and four-year institutions.  The project will map the processes involved and disseminate the project findings widely to ensure that it serves as a model for other institutions that wish to take this approach to improve transfer student success and better prepare all biology majors for the modern STEM workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NEXUS Institute for Quantitative Biology (NIQB) Consortium was established through this award. NIQB, a collaboration between the University of Maryland, Baltimore County (UMBC) and its four key community college partners: Anne Arundel Community College (AACC), Howard Community College (HCC), the Community College of Baltimore County (CCBC), and Montgomery College (MC), worked successfully to strengthen the quantitative reasoning skills of introductory biology students at both two-year and four-year institutions. 

One important outcome of this project was the formation of the many interdisciplinary and inter-institutional collaborative structures that supported the project's work. Approximately 45 biology and math faculty from across the consortium collaborated on curriculum awareness and alignment, which resulted in formal curriculum changes at some of the two-year colleges to better support success of transfer students. Afterwards, faculty worked together to create, implement, and assess quantitative reasoning curriculum modules across consortium institutions in four core introductory biology courses: Introductory Biology I, Introductory Biology II, Genetics, and Cell Biology. Instructional designers were embedded in faculty workgroups to support curriculum and assessment development, and they also designed and delivered high-quality faculty professional development over the course of the project. Formal bi-directional data-sharing agreements between UMBC and each community college, as well as clear data-sharing structures, facilitated data collection and analysis for the project. External evaluation of the consortium's collaboration consistently identified the following strengths: members see collaboration as in their self-interest; skilled leadership; mutual respect understanding, and trust among members; appropriate cross-section of members participating in the project; political and social climate that is favorable to the work of the consortium; and members’ beliefs that the consortium’s work is unique and that no one else in the community is trying to accomplish the same goal.

Another important outcome of the project is the set of 21 quantitative reasoning curriculum modules that were developed, implemented, and assessed across the partner institutions. These modules were designed to build quantitative skills progressively, ensuring that students encountered and reinforced quantitative competencies at multiple points and at increasingly higher levels of difficulty as they moved through the biology core course sequence. At Montgomery College, faculty implemented 16 of the 21 modules. The remaining five cell biology modules could not be implemented during the project due to course enrollment declines. Even so, many of the Introductory Biology I, Introductory Biology II, and Genetics modules have been fully incorporated into to the MC biology curriculum, and faculty continue to use them beyond the formal duration of this award, ensuring their lasting impact on student learning. The modules are publicly available for use by other educators at https://qubeshub.org/community/groups/niqb.

Finally, over 10,000 students were exposed to the quantitative reasoning modules at NIQB Consortium institutions over the course of this project, including many two-year college students. Pre- and post-assessment data demonstrated students' improvements in quantitative reasoning after exposure to the modules, with similar patterns of learning gains across institutions. The NIQB Consortium has not only enhanced quantitative reasoning education in biological sciences, but it has also provided a scalable model for inter-institutional collaboration aimed at improving student success, particularly for students transferring from two-year to four-year institutions.
